title: 110_s851
content: The Act titled "Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2007" introduces the Higher Education Opportunity Credit under Section 25A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit allows eligible students to receive tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. The credit amount is based on the expenses paid during the taxable year, with different percentages for varying expense ranges. There are limitations based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The Higher Education Opportunity Credit provides tax credits for tuition expenses based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with reductions for incomes over $70,000 ($140,000 for joint filers). The term 'modified adjusted gross income' refers to the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year, increased by any excluded amounts under specific sections. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for any taxable year is limited based on the amount of tax, not exceeding the excess of the regular tax liability. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for any taxable year is limited based on the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart and section 27. The credit is only allowed for up to 3 eligible students and for a maximum of 4 taxable years. The credit under subsection (a) is limited based on tax liability and credits allowable under this subpart. The credit can only be claimed for up to 3 eligible students for a maximum of 4 taxable years. An election to apply this section to an eligible student cannot be made if the student had the election in effect for 4 prior taxable years. The credit is only allowed if the student is at least a half-time student for part of the year and is not eligible if the student has been convicted of a felony drug offense. The credit under subsection (a) is not allowed for qualified tuition and related expenses if a student has been convicted of a felony drug offense before the end of the taxable year. An eligible student is defined as someone who meets specific requirements. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 sets criteria for students to qualify for tax credits based on meeting specific requirements and carrying at least half the full-time workload. Qualified tuition and related expenses cover fees for eligible students, including the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 outlines eligibility for tax credits for students attending eligible educational institutions, covering tuition, fees, and 50% of book expenses for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 allows tax credits for eligible students, capping fees at $250 per year. Exceptions include sports-related education and non-academic fees like student activity fees. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for eligible students attending qualified educational institutions. Taxpayers can elect not to apply this section to tuition expenses. No credit is allowed for non-academic fees. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 allows tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses, but taxpayers must include the individual's name and taxpayer identification number on their tax return. Additionally, any amounts paid for the individual's benefit, such as qualified scholarships, will reduce the eligible expenses for the academic period. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. Qualified scholarships, educational assistance allowances, and payments for educational expenses are excluded from gross income. Deductions for dependents under section 151 are also addressed. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. If a deduction for a dependent is allowed to another taxpayer, no credit is allowed to the dependent and their expenses are treated as paid by the other taxpayer. Prepayments for academic periods starting within 3 months after the taxable year are also addressed. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. No credit is allowed if a deduction is already claimed. Married individuals must file jointly for the credit. Nonresident aliens must be treated as residents for the credit to apply. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. Nonresident aliens must be treated as residents for the credit to apply. Inflation adjustments increase dollar amounts for the credit after 2008. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for qualified tuition and related expenses. For taxable years beginning after 2008, income limits are adjusted based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If adjusted amounts are not multiples of $100, they are rounded down. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 offers tax credits for tuition expenses, adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The Secretary can issue regulations for credit recapture in cases of refunds in subsequent years. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides tax credits for tuition expenses, with regulations allowing for credit recapture in cases of refunds in subsequent years. Additionally, the Act repeals the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses, with corresponding amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to make changes to various sections related to tax credits for tuition expenses. This includes amendments to sections 62(a), 72(t)(7), 221(d), and 529, specifically altering references to section 25A in each section. Section 529 and 530 of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to change references to section 25A. Additionally, section 1400O is amended to include a new sentence regarding references to section 25A. Section 1400O of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new sentence regarding references to section 25A. Subsection (e) of section 6050S and subparagraph (J) of section 6213(g)(2) are also amended to update references to section 25A. The table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 is adjusted to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section apply to education expenses paid after December 31, 2007, for academic periods beginning after that date.
